Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Supercritical Carbon Dioxide Assisted Purification of Electrolytically Synthesized Graphite
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is the commercialization of a novel electrolytic process to manufacture low-cost, high-power graphite for electric vehicle batteries. Electrolytically synthesized graphite offers the opportunity to utilize domestically available sources of renewable electricity and carbon dioxide and secure the supply chain for battery production with domestic production capacity. The impact on society that will be created by the commercialization of a novel graphite synthesis process is a significant decrease in graphite manufacturing cost and a more sustainable manufacturing process from domestically available sources of renewable electricity and carbon dioxide.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are to 1) demonstrate effective purification of electrolytically synthesized graphite using supercritical carbon dioxide and 2) recover a high yield of extracted by-products. Currently the purification process mimics the high-temperature thermal purification step of the commercial graphite manufacturing process. However, this process is time consuming, energy intensive, and therefore costly. Supercritical fluids purification has the potential to significantly reduce the purification time, energy cost, and the environmental footprint of electrolytically manufactured graphite. The purification process will be optimized by controlling carbon dioxide pressure, temperature, flow rate, water addition, and extraction time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a result of this Phase I project, Saratoga Energy Research Partners, LLC (Saratoga Energy), located  in Berkeley, CA, has developed a high-selectivity electrochemical process to convert carbon dioxide into carbon nanotubes. In the work conducted thus far, Saratoga Energy has established that its carbon nanotubes (CNTs) can be manufactured at a cost of $5/kg, 50X cheaper than the market price for state-of-the-art battery-grade carbon nanotubes. Carbon nanotubes enable the manufacture high-performance advanced materials and technologies such as lithium-ion batteries, supercapacitors, catalyst supports, water filters, thermally and electrically conductive polymer composites, and power electronics. Due to several unique physical properties and because of rapidly growing demand for electric vehicles, grid energy storage, and consumer electronics, Saratoga Energy has identified lithium-ion batteries as the target entry point into the carbon nanotube market.


During preliminary performance evaluation in lithium-ion half-cells, Saratoga Energy determined that its carbon nanotubes enable the reduction of conductive additive content in the cathode, thus improving specific and volumetric energy density. Similarly, it was found that in the anode, carbon nanotubes enable rapid charge and discharge through improved electronic conductivity and electrolyte penetration, a requirement for electric vehicles and large-scale grid storage for frequency regulation applications. It is expected that this paradigm shift will contribute in a significant way to the use of CNTs in commercial lithium-ion batteries, which, as a result of this unique cost-performance combination, will not only meet existing market needs but also offer the potential to dramatically improve the performance of electric vehicles, grid energy storage, and consumer electronics.


The impact of this Phase I project is multilayered. First, there is the creation of a carbon nanotubes manufacturing industry in this country that will create hundreds of high-paying domestic manufacturing jobs. Secondly, Saratoga Energy’s technology has the potential to benefit the United States economy by increasing the cost competitiveness and performance of lithium-ion batteries, paving the way to the broader adoption of electric vehicles and grid/renewable energy storage. In turn, this will help reduce the strategic importance of oil and the cost of securing global oil supplies as well as reduce greenhouse gas emission.


While lithium-ion batteries were the focus of this body of work, carbon nanotubes are also used in a variety of other applications. These innovations should be broadly applicable to the manufacture of advanced composite materials, nanotechnology, catalyst supports, water filtration, and other areas of interest for the National Science Foundation. Finally, the commercialization of Saratoga Energy’s technology will advance U.S. leadership and knowledge in industrial electrochemistry and the manufacture of high-performance lithium-ion batteries.


Last Modified: 02/27/2018
Modified by: Benjamin M Rush
